I assume that most everyone today is born into a household where some religion is predominant. I personally was born and raised a Baptist, then moved to a Pentecostal Church for a few years before I gave up completely on religion. 
 
 Becoming an Atheist, I don't think, Is something that one chooses to do. You either believe or you don't . I didn't suddenly one day say," hey, I think I will give Atheism a try".. I guess it just is the end result of a long road to discovery.
 
 After 30 some odd years of Living within the Christian Faith , Watching the Bigotry, the hate, the prejudice, hearing the insults, Losing loved ones, And finally becoming disabled through no fault of my own I just finally started to question if God really was up there watching over me. I started off more or less Agnostic, wanting to believe but not sure why. Slowly I began to see things differently, perhaps because after a few years of answering my own questions instead of allowing the " Religion " to answer them for me, I began to lose my belief all together. 
 
 Now, well I'm sure you have seen from my posts here where I stand with religion,lol..
 But, Honestly I don't have a problem with the religion. My view now is that of an Atheist when it comes to my personal belief, My world view has changed from being a hateful, bitter, bigot to " to each his own".. 
 In other words I don't care what other people believe. If they choose to be a Christian then that is their choice. Wanna be a Muslim, hey more power to you. You're Gay?.. nice to meet you. I simply don't care one way or another, because now I look at myself as part of the HUMAN race, just a guy trying to get as much out of this life as I possibly can. I don't live my life worried about my afterlife.

 Talk to Preachers. Talk to Priests. Talk to Atheists, agnostics, Mormons, Muslims, anyone who might have a different perspective. this isnt the first time ive heard someone compare their struggles with atheism to the struggles they faced with their sexuality. personally, i had no problems whatsoever calling myself an atheist. i did so when i was very young, and that confused my parents far more than it confused me. but, i have heard that some people have a pretty hard time with it. they grow up being forced to go to church and believe in this doctrine, and when they start to doubt it, things get rough. this is also not the first time ive heard of people going through a religious "dropping" later in life - most of the time, people become atheists in their teen years, but sometimes earlier (like myself) and sometimes later. it is something you need to think about long and hard, do research on, talk to people, gather up as much experience as you can, but i think it's mainly a personal thing you have to think about. spend some time by yourself reflecting on everything youve experienced and im sure that will make things a whole lot easier.
 
 also something to note is that if you do choose to drop your religious belief, do not be afraid to call yourself an atheist. the term "atheism" gets a lot of bad rep, even from dictionaries which ive seen been defined as "immoral", and a lot of people, especially in America tend to think that atheists are some kind of crazed cult with no moral beliefs that go around fire-bombing churches (thats black metal bands in Finland, btw). this could not be further from the truth. a lack of belief in a religious doctrine will not encourage you to do Hitleresque things or join a cult. atheism is a good thing - a very good thing. atheists will treat you with the same respect as you treat them. atheists will not refuse to be friends with someone based on sexuality, gender, race, political affiliation, social status, or even religious belief. the most bad XXX, hardest hitting atheist in the world, Christopher Hitchens has religious friends. an atheist is a strong title (or lack of title, more appropriately). if someone bites an atheist, they better be prepared to get bitten back, and an atheist bites hard, like Sir Hitchens. an atheist has logic, science, rationality, reason amongst their tool kit, a theist has scripture. an atheist has an open mind and open eyes about everything in this universe, a theist has scripture to tell them about it.

As someone who finally became an atheist a few months ago, I know what you're going through.
 
 I was raised in a religious home -- my dad's a minister, in fact. But it was always a very open-minded home, too. My dad has always been both theologically and politically liberal, and when he got fed up with church politics about twenty years ago, he decided to exchange the pulpit for a job in service to the homeless (shelter, rehab, spiritual guidance, etc). Meanwhile, my mom has always been the sort of preacher's wife whose unorthodox ideas and -ahem- opinionated manner gets her in trouble -- the sort of chick Jesus might have liked, but most church leaders can't stand.
 
 So when I started asking questions -- about why some people are Jewish or Muslim or Hindu or Buddhist (atheism wasn't on the map at first), about why God would punish good people just for not being Christian, about how the Bible could be right if science was, etc -- I was encouraged to explore the possible answers. It made it very easy for me to stay Christian, theologically speaking. There are plenty of liberal options for interpreting the Bible, Christian doctrine, and religion more generally.
 
 Ultimately, though, there's a problem that I've always struggled with, and that's what's known in theological and philosophical circles as "The Problem of Evil." "Evil" is somewhat a misnomer, given modern sensibilities, because we've reduced the term to its moral dimension: sin (in religious terms). But it has always had a natural dimension, too: suffering. In a nutshell, the issue is: How can an all-powerful, perfectly just and benevolent god allow so much innocent suffering? If he is omnipotent, he can stop it. If he's good, he presumably wants there to be less. But there is so much of it -- why? Moral evil -- sin -- is easy enough, that just gets ascribed to human beings. But natural evil -- suffering -- well, that's the tough one. And after years of consideration, I just don't think there's any reasonable solution to the problem, in theological terms. One can take the leap of faith, and say there's a reason for it all, even if we can't know or understand it. But that seems to me no reason at all.
 
 (I should quickly add that this is not to ignore all the goodness and pleasure in the world. It's just that they're not the problem. The undeserved suffering is.)
 
 I've often struggled with other notions, too. Why would God punish all of Adam's descendants for Adam's own failing? Why would he punish anybody's finite crimes on earth with an eternity of torment? Such a deity is not one I could worship. Now in fairness to liberal theists like those in my family, it's not a deity they could worship, either. But they're willing to take the leap of faith, and postulate reasons that (in my view) can't qualify as reasons. So we've parted ways on this.
 
 And amicably, to tell the truth. When I told my father that I no longer believed, what ensued was an outpouring of support -- and then a discussion of the nature of faith, and how it isn't knowledge, and... well, I'll spare you all the details, but it was really excellent. Rarely have I felt so loved. I consider myself quite lucky.
 
 Anyway, I hope that you too will find support from family, from friends, from somewhere. It's not an easy thing to do, but in the long run, you'll be happier. Like you said, it's not unlike coming out.
 
 (And needless to say, I concur with much of what Bennedict and Xcaliber and others have been saying.)
